title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that law enforcement officers face increasing challenges in the war against drugs and crime, with a rise in violent crime and drug use. The support from the Federal Government has not kept pace with these evolving issues, and a review is needed to evaluate current problems. A review twenty-five years later would help evaluate current problems in law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, including the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibility for crime control, would assist in redefining relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. Establishment of the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" (referred to as the "Commission") with duties outlined. The Commission will study and recommend changes related to law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, and cooperation among different agencies. The Commission will conduct surveys and consult with law enforcement officers, officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information on important law enforcement issues. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the House, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members from national law enforcement organizations and individuals with academic expertise on law enforcement issues. Appointments are made by leaders in the House, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House, Senate, and the President, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations, academic experts, and representatives from federal law enforcement, Department of Justice, and State or local government entities. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House, Senate, and the President, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations, academic experts, and representatives from federal law enforcement, Department of Justice, and State or local government entities. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity and oversees the methodology of the Commission's study. Members select a chairperson upon appointment and receive no compensation. The Commission, consisting of 25 members appointed by various leaders, selects a chairperson and receives no additional compensation. Members are entitled to travel expenses as per regulations and must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested by the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, under Section 7 of the Act, has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate authority, obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts and donations, and use the United States mails. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit a report as outlined in Section 8. The Commission established by the Act has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, and submit a report to Congress within eighteen months. Upon submitting the report, the Commission will cease to exist, and certain sections of previous legislation will be repealed.
